skill.name: multi-cloud-architecture
skill.description: Design multi-cloud architectures using a decision framework to select and integrate services across AWS, Azure, and GCP. Use when building multi-cloud systems, avoiding vendor lock-in, or leveraging best-of-breed services from multiple providers.
skill.summary: Design multi-cloud architectures using a decision framework to select and integrate services across ...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and configuration files with no executable code. It is a pure prompt-based skill that provides architectural guidance for multi-cloud systems.

content.value_statement: Designing applications that span multiple cloud providers introduces complexity in service selection and vendor lock-in concerns. This skill provides a decision framework to compare AWS, Azure, and GCP services and implement cloud-agnostic architectures.
actual_capabilities: Compare compute services across AWS, Azure, and GCP
Evaluate storage and database options for multi-cloud deployments
Apply multi-cloud architecture patterns like DR and best-of-breed
Design cloud-agnostic architectures using abstraction layers
Implement cost optimization strategies across cloud providers
Plan migration strategies for multi-cloud environments
limitations: Does not execute or deploy infrastructure code
Does not access cloud provider APIs or credentials
Does not generate Terraform or other IaC configurations
Does not provide real-time pricing data

use_cases.title: Design vendor-neutral systems
use_cases.description: Create architectures that avoid lock-in by using abstraction layers and cloud-agnostic patterns.

use_cases.title: Plan cloud migrations
use_cases.description: Develop migration strategies with phased approaches and disaster recovery planning.

use_cases.title: Evaluate multi-cloud strategies
use_cases.description: Assess trade-offs between cloud providers for specific workloads and business requirements.

prompt_templates.title: Compare compute options
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare ECS, Azure Container Instances, and Cloud Run for hosting containerized microservices. Include scaling characteristics and pricing models.

prompt_templates.title: Select database platform
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me select between DynamoDB, Cosmos DB, and Firestore for a global application with low-latency requirements. Consider consistency models and pricing.

prompt_templates.title: Design DR strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a multi-cloud disaster recovery pattern for a Tier-1 application. Include data replication and failover procedures.

prompt_templates.title: Create abstraction layer
prompt_templates.prompt: How should I structure a Kubernetes application to abstract cloud-specific services? Provide a reference architecture with abstraction patterns.

output_examples.input: Compare AWS Lambda, Azure Functions, and Cloud Functions for event-driven workloads
output: Compute: AWS Lambda supports 15min timeout, Azure Functions up to 10min, Cloud Functions 9min
Memory range: Lambda 128MB-10GB, Azure 128MB-1.5GB, Cloud Functions 128MB-2GB
Cold start: Lambda ~500ms, Azure ~1-2s, Cloud Functions ~100-500ms
Free tier: Lambda 1M requests + 400K GB-s, Azure 1M requests, Cloud Functions 2M invocations
Recommendation: GCP for lowest cold start, Lambda for mature ecosystem, Azure for Microsoft workloads

best_practices: Use infrastructure as code (Terraform/OpenTofu) to manage multi-cloud deployments consistently
Design for failure by implementing health checks, circuit breakers, and automated failover across clouds
Implement abstraction layers using Kubernetes and open standards to minimize provider-specific code
anti_patterns: Duplicating cloud-specific logic throughout the application instead of abstracting at the infrastructure layer
Using managed services from each cloud without evaluating total cost of ownership and operational overhead
Neglecting data transfer costs when distributing workloads across multiple cloud providers

faq.question: Which cloud should I choose as primary?
faq.answer: Base your decision on team expertise, existing investments, and specific service requirements. Evaluate managed services, pricing, and support needs.

faq.question: What are realistic multi-cloud costs?
faq.answer: Expect 15-30% overhead from data transfer, duplicate tooling, and increased operational complexity. Factor in training and certification costs.

faq.question: How does this integrate with Terraform skills?
faq.answer: Use this skill for architectural decisions, then combine with terraform-module-library skill to implement infrastructure as code patterns.

faq.question: Is my data safe in multi-cloud setups?
faq.answer: Data safety depends on encryption, access controls, and compliance configurations. This skill describes patterns; implementation requires security expertise.

faq.question: Why is my multi-cloud app slower?
faq.answer: Cross-cloud network latency typically adds 20-50ms per hop. Optimize by placing workloads close to users and minimizing cross-cloud data transfers.

faq.question: How does this compare to single-cloud approaches?
faq.answer: Multi-cloud increases flexibility and reduces vendor lock-in risk but adds complexity. Single-cloud simplifies operations and often reduces costs for standard workloads.
